member.name: T:Facepunch.ActionGraphs.ActionGraph
member.summary: Represents an async method as a directed graph. Control will enter through an "event" node, which can route signals through a network of other nodes that perform actions. Use to create a completely blank graph, or to create a graph that handles an event matching the signature of a particular delegate.

member.name: T:Facepunch.ActionGraphs.SerializationOptions
member.summary: Controls how s are (de)serialized.
member.param: Add this input to any graphs deserialized in this scope, usually representing a "this" parameter holding the object this graph is embedded in. When serializing, omit this input from the serialized graph because we know it will be added automatically when deserializing.

Re-use instances from this cache when deserializing, matching by . Graphs will be added to the cache when serializing or deserializing in this scope. When serializing, if is true, a minimal graph reference stub will be written instead of full graphs.
For debugging / editors, describe where graphs deserialized in this scope came from.
When deserializing, maps any graph s encountered.
If true, and a is provided, write a reference stub when serializing graphs instead of the full JSON.
If true, replace cached instance when deserializing. Otherwise, it'll only be replaced if its differs.

member.name: T:Facepunch.ActionGraphs.Compilation.ValueScope
member.summary: Wraps a set of value inputs of action nodes that should be evaluated at the same time. Each referenced expression node in the scope will be evaluated at most once, so if the result of a node is used multiple times it will have the same value. This is both an optimization, and expected behaviour if things like random numbers are sampled.

member.name: M:Facepunch.ActionGraphs.DisplayInfo.ParameterPattern
member.remarks:
Pattern:
\\{\\s*(?<name>[a-zA-Z_]+)\\s*(?:\\:\\s*(?<format>[^}|]+\\s*))?(?:\\|\\s*(?<default>[^}]*)\\s*)?\\}
Explanation:
Match '{'.
Match a whitespace character atomically any number of times.
"name" capture group.
Match a character in the set [A-Z_a-z] greedily at least once.
Match a whitespace character greedily any number of times.
Optional (greedy).
Match ':'.
Match a whitespace character greedily any number of times.
"format" capture group.
Match a character in the set [^|}] greedily at least once.
Match a whitespace character greedily any number of times.
Optional (greedy).
Match '|'.
Match a whitespace character greedily any number of times.
"default" capture group.
Match a character other than '}' greedily any number of times.
Match a whitespace character atomically any number of times.
Match '}'.

member.name: T:Facepunch.ActionGraphs.Node
member.summary: The main building block of an action graph. Represents either an action or expression. An action node has input and output signals, and will act only when receiving a signal. Expression nodes have only input and output values, and will be evaluated lazily when one of its outputs is requested.

member.name: M:Sandbox.AppSystem.LoadSteamDll
member.summary: Explicitly load the Steam Api dll from our bin folder, so that it doesn't accidentally load one from c:\system32\ or something. This is a problem when people have installed pirate versions of Steam in the past and have the assembly hanging around still. By loading it here we're saying use this version, and it won't try to load another one.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Audio.AudioSampler
member.summary:
A wrapper around CAudioMixer, which is used in c++ to read from a wav etc. This has two parts.
o Sample - reads the samples, advances the index o GetSamples - returns the samples.
The reason it's coded like this is because each mix frame we read all samples, then the mixers can do whatever they want with them. So rather than have the mixers fight over reading and advancing, they can all get the samples if they want to.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Engine.BindCollection
member.summary:
A collection of action binds.
BindCollection - Action: attack1 - Slot0: mouse1 - Action: selectall - Slot0: ctrl + a
The bind collection can be saved and loaded from disk via the BindSaveConfig class.
The bind collection can have a base collection which it will fall back to if it contains the same binds. This allows us to have a "common" collection which can be shared between all games, but can also let the games + users to override those binds if they choose.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Engine.WebSocket
member.summary: A WebSocket client for connecting to external services.
member.remarks: Events handlers will be called on the synchronization context that was called on.

member.param: The message text that was received.

member.summary: Event handler which processes binary messages from the WebSocket service.
member.param: The binary message data that was received.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Engine.WebSocket.DisconnectedHandler
member.summary: Event handler which fires when the WebSocket disconnects from the server.
member.param: The close status code from the server, or 0 if there was none. See known values here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CloseEvent
The reason string for closing the connection. This may not be populated, may be from the server, or may be a client exception message.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Engine.WebSocket.IsConnected
member.summary: Returns true as long as a WebSocket connection is established.

member.summary: Get the sub-protocol that was negotiated during the opening handshake.

member.summary: Event which fires when a binary message is received from the server.

member.summary: Event which fires when the connection to the WebSocket service is lost, for any reason.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Engine.WebSocket.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialized a new WebSocket client.
member.param: The maximum message size to allow from the server, in bytes. Default 64 KiB.

member.summary: Cleans up resources used by the WebSocket client. This will also immediately close the connection if it is currently open.

member.summary: Add a sub-protocol to be negotiated during the WebSocket connection handshake.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Engine.WebSocket.Connect(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Establishes a connection to an external WebSocket service.
member.param: The WebSocket URI to connect to. For example, "ws://hostname.local:1280/" for unencrypted WebSocket or "wss://hostname.local:1281/" for encrypted.
A which allows the connection attempt to be aborted if necessary.
member.returns: A which completes when the connection is established, or throws if it failed to connect.

member.summary: Sends a text message to the WebSocket server.

member.summary: Sends a binary message to the WebSocket server.

member.returns: A which completes when the message was queued to be sent.

member.summary: Sends a binary message to the WebSocket server.

member.summary: Sends a binary message to the WebSocket server.
member.param: The message data to send.
member.returns: A which completes when the message was queued to be sent.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Engine.Utility.RayTrace.MeshTraceRequest.Result.HitTriangleUv
member.summary: This is the Uv coordinate on the triangle hit. 'x' represents the distance between Vertex 0-1, 'y' represents the distance between Vertex 0-2.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Engine.Utility.RayTrace.MeshTraceRequest.Result.VertexInfluence
member.summary: Given the position on the triangle hit, this vector gives the influence of each vertex on that position. So for example, if the Vector is [1,0,0] that means that the hit point is right on vertex 0. If it's [0.33, 0.33, 0.33] then it's right in the middle of each vertex.

member.name: P:Sandbox.CookieItem.DeleteAt
member.summary:
If set to non 0, this key will be deleted at/after given time. This is useful in case you didn't open your game for more than 30 days (which is the default expiry time), and then you lose all your cookies because they all are expired and get deleted on launch.
This way you have a 24 hour grace period.

For example, a map package might use a model package - but there is no need to download that model package because any usage will organically be included in the manifest. However, when loading this item in the editor, it'd make sense to install these 'cloud' packages.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Navigation.NavMesh.GenerateTile(Sandbox.PhysicsWorld,Vector3)
member.summary: Generates or regenerates the navmesh tile at the given world position. This function is thread safe but can only be called from the main thread.
member.remarks: While most of the generation happens in parallel, this function also requires some time on the main thread. If you need to update many tiles, consider spreading the updates accross multiple frames.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Navigation.NavMesh.GenerateTiles(Sandbox.PhysicsWorld,BBox)
member.summary: Generates or regenerates the navmesh tiles overlapping with the given bounds. This function is thread safe but can only be called from the main thread.
member.remarks: While most of the generation happens in parallel, this function also requires some time on the main thread. If you need to update many tiles, consider spreading the updates accross multiple frames.

member.summary: Calculates the specified percentile value from the collected samples.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Services.BenchmarkSystem.Sampler.Stuttering(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the sum of all samples that exceeded the stuttering threshold. A sample is considered stuttering if it exceeds the moving average multiplied by the stuttering factor.
member.param: The multiplier used to determine the stuttering threshold. A higher factor makes it less sensitive to spikes (default is typically 2.5).

summary.para:
VR overlays draw over the top of the 3D scene, they will not be affected by lighting, post processing effects or anything else in the world.
This makes them ideal for HUDs or menus, or anything else that should be local to the HMD or tracked devices.
If you need something in the world, consider using WorldPanel and WorldInput instead.

member.summary: Use to draw overlay as a curved surface. Curvature is a percentage from (0..1] where 1 is a fully closed cylinder. For a specific radius, curvature can be computed as: overlay.width / (2 PI r).

member.name: M:Sandbox.Interop.GetTemporaryStringPointerForNative(System.String)
member.summary: This is called when native calls a managed function and it returns a string. In this case we can't free the string immediately, so we store it in a list and free it at the end of the frame. This has potential to crash, if we free the string before the thread uses it but this would be super rare and the other option is to never return strings like this.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Network.ConnectionInfo
member.summary: Information about a connection. The difference between this and the actual connections is that this can be networked between clients, so all clients have the same information about each other. This is going to be required in p2p games, where players need to take over hosting from each other. In a game like Rust, with a dedicated server, this won't need to be networked to other clients.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Networking.SetData(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Set data about the current server or lobby. Other players can query this when searching for a game. Note: for now, try to keep the key and value as short as possible, Steam enforce a character limit on server tags, so it could be possible to reach that limit when running a Dedicated Server. In the future we'll store this stuff on our backend, so that won't be a problem.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.Unreliable
member.summary: Message will be sent unreliably. It may not arrive and it may be received out of order. But chances are that it will arrive on time and everything will be fine. This is good for sending position updates, or spawning effects. This is the fastest way to send a message. It is also the cheapest.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.Reliable
member.summary: Message will be sent reliably. Multiple attempts will be made until the recipient has received it. Use this for things like chat messages, or important events. This is the slowest way to send a message. It is also the most expensive.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.SendImmediate
member.summary: Message will not be grouped up with other messages, and will be sent immediately. This is most useful for things like streaming voice data, where packets need to stream in real-time, rather than arriving with a bunch of other packets.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.DiscardOnDelay
member.summary: Message will be dropped if it can't be sent quickly. Only applicable to unreliable messages.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.HostOnly
member.summary: Only the host may call this action

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.OwnerOnly
member.summary: Only the owner may call this action

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetFlags.UnreliableNoDelay
member.summary: Message will be sent unreliably, not grouped up with other messages and will be dropped if it can't be sent quickly.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Physics.CollisionRules.Clean

member.name: P:Sandbox.Physics.PhysicsSettings.UseFixedUpdate
member.summary: If false, then instead of operating physics, and UpdateFixed in a fixed update frequency they will be called the same as Update - every frame, with a variable time delta.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Physics.PhysicsSettings.SubSteps
member.summary: If you're seeing objects go through other objects or you have a low tickrate, you might want to increase the number of physics substeps. This breaks physics steps down into this many substeps. The default is 1 and works pretty good. Be aware that the number of physics ticks per second is going to be tickrate * substeps. So if you're ticking at 90 and you have SubSteps set to 1000 then you're going to do 90,000 steps per second. So be careful here.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Physics.PhysicsSettings.FixedUpdateFrequency
member.summary: How many times a second FixedUpdate runs

member.name: P:Sandbox.Physics.PhysicsSettings.MaxFixedUpdates
member.summary: If the frame took longer than a FixedUpdate step, we need to run multiple steps for that frame, to catch up. How many are allowed? Too few, and the simluation will run slower than the game. If you allow an unlimited amount then the frame time could snowball to infinity and never catch up.

member.name: P:Sandbox.PhysicsBody.UseController
member.summary: If true we'll create a controller for this physics body. This is useful for keyframed physics objects that need to push things. The controller will sweep as the entity moves, rather than teleporting the object.. which works better when pushing dynamic objects etc.

member.summary:
Sets on all shapes of this body.
Returns true if ANY of the physics shapes have persistent touch events enabled.

member.summary:
Sets on all shapes of this body.

member.name: P:Sandbox.PhysicsBody.NavmeshBodyTypeOverride
member.summary: The bodytype may change between edit and game time. For navmesh generation we always need to know the bodytype at game time. This override can be set to inform the navmesh generation of the correct game time bodytype.

member.name: P:Sandbox.PhysicsWorld.SubSteps
member.summary: If you're seeing objects go through other objects or you have a low tickrate, you might want to increase the number of physics substeps. This breaks physics steps down into this many substeps. The default is 1 and works pretty good. Be aware that the number of physics ticks per second is going to be tickrate * substeps. So if you're ticking at 90 and you have SubSteps set to 1000 then you're going to do 90,000 steps per second. So be careful here.

member.name: T:Sandbox.ComputeShader
member.summary: A compute shader is a program that runs on the GPU, often with data provided to/from the CPU by means of a or a .

member.summary: Attributes that are passed to the compute shader on dispatch.

member.summary: Create a compute shader from the specified path.

member.name: M:Sandbox.ComputeShader.Dispatch(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Dispatch this compute shader using explicit thread counts.
member.remarks:
The specified thread counts will be automatically divided by the thread group size defined in the shader to compute the final dispatch group count.
When called outside a graphics context, the dispatch runs immediately. When called inside a graphics context, the dispatch runs async.
member.param: The number of threads to dispatch in the X dimension.
The number of threads to dispatch in the Y dimension.
The number of threads to dispatch in the Z dimension.

member.name: M:Sandbox.ComputeShader.DispatchIndirect(Sandbox.GpuBuffer,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Dispatch this compute shader by reading thread group counts (x, y, z) from an indirect buffer of type .

remarks.para: must be created with and have an element size of 12 bytes.
is an element index into , not a byte offset.
When called outside a graphics context, the dispatch runs immediately. When called inside a graphics context, the dispatch runs async.

member.param: The GPU buffer containing one or more dispatch argument entries.
The index of the dispatch arguments element to use (each element = 12 bytes).

member.name: M:Sandbox.CubemapRendering.SumOfSquaresTwo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the sum of squares of powers of two up to n. Formula: 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 + ... + (2^k) where 2^k n Used for determining compute shader dispatch dimensions.
member.param: The upper limit for powers of two.
member.returns: The sum of squares of powers of two up to n.

member.name: T:Sandbox.GpuBuffer
member.summary:
A GPU data buffer intended for use with a .
You can read and write arbitrary data to and from the CPU and GPU. This allows for efficient parallel data processing on the GPU.
Different GPU buffer types can be used depending on the provided . Using the default type buffers map to StructuredBuffer<T> and RWStructuredBuffer<T> in HLSL.

member.name: P:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.ElementCount
member.summary: Number of elements in the buffer.

member.name: P:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.ElementSize
member.summary: Size of a single element in the buffer.

member.name: P:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.Usage
member.summary: What sort of buffer this is

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,Sandbox.GpuBuffer.UsageFlags,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new GPU buffer with a specified number of elements and a specific buffer type.
member.param: The total number of elements that the GpuBuffer can hold. This represents the buffer's size in terms of elements, not bytes.
The total number of elements that the GpuBuffer can hold. This represents the buffer's size in terms of elements, not bytes.
Defines the usage pattern of the GPU buffer. This can affect performance depending on how the buffer is utilized.
Test

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.Dispose
member.summary: Destroys the GPU buffer, don't use it no more

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.GetData``1(System.Span{``0})
member.summary: Retrieves the GPU buffer and copies them into a provided Span.
member.remarks: This operation is synchronous and will block until the data has been fully downloaded from the GPU.
member.param: A Span of type T which the GPU buffer's contents will be copied into.

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.GetData``1(System.Span{``0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a number of elements from the GPU buffer and copies them into a provided Span.
member.remarks: This operation is synchronous and will block until the specified range of data has been fully downloaded from the GPU.
member.param: A Span of type T which the GPU buffer's contents will be copied into.
The starting index from which to begin retrieving data. This index is in terms of elements, not bytes.
The number of elements to retrieve from the GPU buffer. This count is also in terms of elements, not bytes.

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.SetData``1(System.Span{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Synchronously uploads data from a Span to the GPU, replacing the existing data in this GpuBuffer.
member.remarks: This operation is synchronous; it will block until the data has been fully uploaded to the GPU.
member.param: The Span of data to upload. It should contain items of type T, which is a struct.
The offset in terms of elements (not bytes) at which to start uploading data (default is 0).

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.SetData``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Synchronously uploads data from a List to the GPU, replacing the existing data in this GpuBuffer.
member.remarks: This operation is synchronous; it will block until the data has been fully uploaded to the GPU.
member.param: The List of data to upload. It should contain items of type T, which is a struct.
The offset in terms of elements (not bytes) at which to start uploading data (default is 0).

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.CopyStructureCount(Sandbox.GpuBuffer,System.Int32)
member.summary: For buffers there is a hidden uint 32-bit atomic counter in the buffer that contains the number of writes to the buffer after invocation of the compute shader. In order to get the value of the counter, the data needs to be copied to another GPU buffer that can be used.

member.name: M:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.SetCounterValue(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Sets the counter value for or structured buffers.

member.name: T:Sandbox.GpuBuffer.UsageFlags
member.summary: You can combine these e.g UsageFlags.Index | UsageFlags.ByteAddress for a buffer that can be used as an index buffer and in a compute shader.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Graphics

member.name: P:Sandbox.Graphics.LayerType

member.name: M:Sandbox.Graphics.DrawModelInstanced(Sandbox.Model,System.Span{Transform},Sandbox.RenderAttributes)
member.summary:
Draws multiple instances of a model using GPU instancing, assuming standard implemented shaders.
Use `CalculateInstancingObjectToWorldMatrix` in shaders to access the instance transform.
There is a limit of 1,048,576 transform slots per frame when using this method.
member.param: The model to draw
Instance transform data to draw
Optional attributes to apply only for this draw call

member.name: M:Sandbox.Graphics.DrawModelInstancedIndirect(Sandbox.Model,Sandbox.GpuBuffer,System.Int32,Sandbox.RenderAttributes)
member.summary: Draws multiple instances of a model using GPU instancing with the number of instances being provided by indirect draw arguments. Use `SV_InstanceID` semantic in shaders to access the rendered instance.
member.param: The model to draw
The GPU buffer containing the DrawIndirectArguments
Optional offset in the GPU buffer
Optional attributes to apply only for this draw call

member.name: M:Sandbox.Graphics.DrawModelInstanced(Sandbox.Model,System.Int32,Sandbox.RenderAttributes)
member.summary:
Draws multiple instances of a model using GPU instancing. This is similar to , except the count is provided from the CPU rather than via a GPU buffer.
Use `SV_InstanceID` semantic in shaders to access the rendered instance.
member.param: The model to draw
The number of instances to draw
Optional attributes to apply only for this draw call

member.name: M:Sandbox.RenderTarget.GetTemporary(System.Int32,System.Int32,Sandbox.ImageFormat,Sandbox.ImageFormat,Sandbox.MultisampleAmount,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a temporary render target. You should dispose the returned handle when you're done to return the textures to the pool.
member.param: Width of the render target you want.
Height of the render target you want.
The format for the color buffer. If set to default we'll use whatever the current pipeline is using.
The format for the depth buffer.
The number of msaa samples you'd like. Msaa render textures are a pain in the ass so you're probably gonna regret trying to use this.
Number of mips you want in this texture. You probably don't want this unless you want to generate mips in a second pass.

member.summary: Get a temporary render target. You should dispose the returned handle when you're done to return the textures to the pool.
member.param: Divide the screen size by this factor. 2 would be half screen sized. 1 for full screen sized.
The format for the color buffer. If null we'll choose the most appropriate for where you are in the pipeline.
The format for the depth buffer.
The number of msaa samples you'd like. Msaa render textures are a pain in the ass so you're probably gonna regret trying to use this.
Number of mips you want in this texture. You probably don't want this unless you want to generate mips in a second pass.
member.returns: A RenderTarget that is ready to render to.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Resources.EmbeddedResource
member.summary:
A JSON definition of an embedded resource. This is a resource that can be either standalone (in a .vtex file) or embedded in a GameResource's Json data.
When it's detected in a GameResource we will create the named compiler and create the resource. When compiling the GameResource this can optionally create a compiled version of the resource on disk.
When we compile a regular resource that contains this $compiler structure, it operates like any other compile, except it's totally managed by c# instead of resourcecompiler.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Resources.EmbeddedResource.ResourceCompiler
member.summary: The name of the ResourceCompiler to use

member.name: P:Sandbox.Resources.EmbeddedResource.ResourceGenerator
member.summary: The name of the ResourceGenerator that created this resource. This is basically a sub-compiler.

member.summary: Data that is serialized/deserialized from the ResourceGenerator

member.summary: If this resource has been compiled to disk then this is the path to that resource. This avoids the need to generate this resource again.

member.summary: The absolute path to the resource on disk

member.summary: The resource version can be important

member.name: M:Sandbox.Texture.CopyFrom(Sandbox.Texture)
member.summary: Replace our strong handle with a copy of the strong handle of the passed texture Which means that this texture will invisibly become that texture. I suspect that there might be a decent way to do this in native using the resource system. In which case we should change all this code to use that way instead of doing this.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Texture.Dispose
member.summary: Will release the handle for this texture. If the texture isn't referenced by anything else it'll be released properly. This will happen anyway because it's called in the destructor. By calling it manually you're just telling the engine you're done with this texture right now instead of waiting for the garbage collector.

member.name: P:Sandbox.SceneCamera.ZFar
member.summary: The camera's zFar distance. This is the furthest distance this camera will be able to render. This value totally depends on the game you're making. Shorter the better, sensible ranges would be between about 1000 and 30000, but if you want it to be further out you can balance that out by making znear larger.

member.name: P:Sandbox.SceneCamera.ZNear
member.summary: The camera's zNear distance. This is the closest distance this camera will be able to render. A good value for this is about 5. Below 5 and particularly below 1 you're going to start to see a lot of artifacts like z-fighting.

member.name: T:Sandbox.SceneParticles
member.summary: A SceneObject used to render particles. We need to be careful with what we do here, because this object is created for in-engine particles as well as custom scene object particles. With custom particles there's no automatic Simulate, or deletion.. You're completely on your own. This is perhaps a good thing though, it's maybe what you want to happen. To be completely isolated and completely in control. But at the same time maybe it's not and it's something we need to sort out.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition
member.summary: Defines characteristics of an object type that should be tracked within a JSON tree structure. These definitions are used to identify, track, and manage specific types of objects during JSON diffing and patching operations.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.Type
member.summary: A unique identifier for this object type. This is used to categorize objects.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.MatchScore
member.summary: Determines whether a JSON object should be considered an instance of this tracked object type.
member.remarks: The function returns a float value indicating how well the JSON object matches this definition. A return value of 0 indicates no match, while higher values indicate stronger matches. This allows for heuristic-based matching when exact matches aren't possible.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.ToId
member.summary: Maps a JSON object to a unique identifier string.
member.remarks:
The identifier could be derived from a specific property, a combination of properties, or a computed hash. It's critical that this function: 1. Produces a truly unique value for each distinct object of this type 2. Never maps two different objects to the same ID 3. Is deterministic - always returns the same ID when applied to the same object
If you can just use a UUID or other guaranteed unique identifier.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.ParentType
member.summary: Specifies the required type of the parent object. If null, AllowedAsRoot must be true.
member.remarks: This enforces type hierarchy constraints within the JSON structure.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.AllowedAsRoot
member.summary: If true, objects of this type can be the root of the object tree.
member.remarks: Root objects don't require a parent, and they don't need an ID since there can only be one root. If AllowedAsRoot is false, ParentType must be specified.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition.CreatePresenceBasedDefinition(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String},System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a TrackedObjectDefinition that identifies objects based on the presence of specific fields.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.Id
member.summary: The unique identifier for this object

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.Data
member.summary: The object's JSON data without its children

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.Parent
member.summary: Reference to this object's parent (null for root objects)

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.ContainerProperty
member.summary: The property name in parent that contains this object

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.IsContainedInArray
member.summary: Whether this object is contained in an array (true) or as a direct property (false)

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.PreviousElement
member.summary: The previous sibling element when contained in an array (null if first or not in array)

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.Path
member.summary: The path to this object in the JSON structure

member.name: F:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.Children
member.summary: Child objects belonging to this object

member.name: M:Sandbox.Json.TrackedObject.ToJson
member.summary: Reconstructs a complete JSON tree from this object and all its children.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Json.Patch
member.summary: Represents a complete set of changes to be applied to a JSON structure.
member.remarks: A patch contains all the operations needed to transform one JSON structure into another while preserving object identity and relationships.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Json.CalculateDifferences(System.Text.Json.Nodes.JsonObject,System.Text.Json.Nodes.JsonObject,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition})
member.summary: Compares two JSON object trees and calculates the differences between them.
member.param: The original JSON object tree
The updated JSON object tree
Set of definitions for tracked object types in the JSON structure
member.returns: A Patch object containing all changes needed to transform oldRoot into newRoot

member.name: M:Sandbox.Json.ApplyPatch(System.Text.Json.Nodes.JsonObject,Sandbox.Json.Patch,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{Sandbox.Json.TrackedObjectDefinition})
member.summary: Applies a patch to transform a JSON object tree, with support for partial patch application when the source tree has been modified after the patch was created.
member.param: The JSON object tree to modify
The patch containing all changes to apply
Set of definitions for tracked object types
member.returns: A new JSON object tree with all applicable changes applied
member.remarks:
Partial patch application semantics:
Object Removal: - Skipped if object doesn't exist in source - Proceeds if object exists even if parent has changed
Object Addition: - Only added if parent exists in source - Skipped if parent is missing
Object Moves: - Requires both object and target parent to exist - Object is removed if target parent doesn't exist
Property Overrides: - Only applied if target object exists
Array Ordering: - Best effort based on neighbourhood information (previous element) - Objects without previous elements are placed at start
Operations are processed in this order: removals, additions, moves, reordering, and finally property overrides.

member.name: P:Sandbox.WebSurface.InBackgroundMode
member.summary: Enable/disable low-resource background mode, where javascript and repaint timers are throttled, resources are more aggressively purged from memory, and audio/video elements are paused. When background mode is enabled, all HTML5 video and audio objects will execute ".pause()" and gain the property "._steam_background_paused = 1". When background mode is disabled, any video or audio objects with that property will resume with ".play()".

members.member: For objects that can't be considered to be "owned" by the world they are in because they are owned by a manager. All this flag does is cause a warning when such an object is still in the world at world deletion time (a leak).

if this flag is set, then the object will not be deleted when deleting the world, and will not be queued for delete. It's assumed that this object is going to be deleted inside of the destructor of another sceneobject

Represents a dynamic polygon corridor used to plan agent movement. @ingroup crowd, detour

@class dtPathCorridor @par
The corridor is loaded with a path, usually obtained from a #dtNavMeshQuery::findPath() query. The corridor is then used to plan local movement, with the corridor automatically updating as needed to deal with inaccurate agent locomotion.
Example of a common use case:
-# Construct the corridor object and call #init() to allocate its path buffer. -# Obtain a path from a #dtNavMeshQuery object. -# Use #reset() to set the agent's current position. (At the beginning of the path.) -# Use #setCorridor() to load the path and target. -# Use #findCorners() to plan movement. (This handles dynamic path straightening.) -# Use #movePosition() to feed agent movement back into the corridor. (The corridor will automatically adjust as needed.) -# If the target is moving, use #moveTargetPosition() to update the end of the corridor. (The corridor will automatically adjust as needed.) -# Repeat the previous 3 steps to continue to move the agent.
The corridor position and target are always constrained to the navigation mesh.
One of the difficulties in maintaining a path is that floating point errors, locomotion inaccuracies, and/or local steering can result in the agent crossing the boundary of the path corridor, temporarily invalidating the path. This class uses local mesh queries to detect and update the corridor as needed to handle these types of issues.
The fact that local mesh queries are used to move the position and target locations results in two beahviors that need to be considered:
Every time a move function is used there is a chance that the path will become non-optimial. Basically, the further the target is moved from its original location, and the further the position is moved outside the original corridor, the more likely the path will become non-optimal. This issue can be addressed by periodically running the #optimizePathTopology() and #optimizePathVisibility() methods.
All local mesh queries have distance limitations. (Review the #dtNavMeshQuery methods for details.) So the most accurate use case is to move the position and target in small increments. If a large increment is used, then the corridor may not be able to accurately find the new location. Because of this limiation, if a position is moved in a large increment, then compare the desired and resulting polygon references. If the two do not match, then path replanning may be needed. E.g. If you move the target, check #getLastPoly() to see if it is the expected polygon.
Gets the current position within the corridor. (In the first polygon.) @return The current position within the corridor.
Gets the current target within the corridor. (In the last polygon.) @return The current target within the corridor.

The corridor's path. @return The corridor's path. [(polyRef) * #getPathCount()]
The number of polygons in the current corridor path. @return The number of polygons in the current corridor path.

@par
This method is meant to be used for quick, short distance checks.
If the path array is too small to hold the result, it will be filled as far as possible from the start postion toward the end position.
Using the Hit Parameter (t)
If the hit parameter is a very high value (FLT_MAX), then the ray has hit the end position. In this case the path represents a valid corridor to the end position and the value of @p hitNormal is undefined.
If the hit parameter is zero, then the start position is on the wall that was hit and the value of @p hitNormal is undefined.
If 0 < t < 1.0 then the following applies:
@code distanceToHitBorder = distanceToEndPosition * t hitPoint = startPos + (endPos - startPos) * t @endcode
Use Case Restriction
The raycast ignores the y-value of the end position. (2D check.) This places significant limits on how it can be used. For example:
Consider a scene where there is a main floor with a second floor balcony that hangs over the main floor. So the first floor mesh extends below the balcony mesh. The start position is somewhere on the first floor. The end position is on the balcony.
The raycast will search toward the end position along the first floor mesh. If it reaches the end position's xz-coordinates it will indicate FLT_MAX (no wall hit), meaning it reached the end position. This is one example of why this method is meant for short distance checks.

@par
This method is meant to be used for quick, short distance checks.
If the path array is too small to hold the result, it will be filled as far as possible from the start postion toward the end position.
Using the Hit Parameter t of RaycastHit
If the hit parameter is a very high value (FLT_MAX), then the ray has hit the end position. In this case the path represents a valid corridor to the end position and the value of @p hitNormal is undefined.
If the hit parameter is zero, then the start position is on the wall that was hit and the value of @p hitNormal is undefined.
If 0 < t < 1.0 then the following applies:
@code distanceToHitBorder = distanceToEndPosition * t hitPoint = startPos + (endPos - startPos) * t @endcode
Use Case Restriction
The raycast ignores the y-value of the end position. (2D check.) This places significant limits on how it can be used. For example:
Consider a scene where there is a main floor with a second floor balcony that hangs over the main floor. So the first floor mesh extends below the balcony mesh. The start position is somewhere on the first floor. The end position is on the balcony.
The raycast will search toward the end position along the first floor mesh. If it reaches the end position's xz-coordinates it will indicate FLT_MAX (no wall hit), meaning it reached the end position. This is one example of why this method is meant for short distance checks.

The id of the offmesh connection. (User assigned when the navigation mesh is built.)
Defines a polygon within a dtMeshTile object. @ingroup detour
Index to first link in linked list. (Or #DT_NULL_LINK if there is no link.)
The indices of the polygon's vertices. The actual vertices are located in dtMeshTile::verts.
Packed data representing neighbor polygons references and flags for each edge.
The user defined polygon flags.
The number of vertices in the polygon.
The bit packed area id and polygon type. @note Use the structure's set and get methods to access this value.
Sets the user defined area id. [Limit: < #DT_MAX_AREAS]
Sets the polygon type. (See: #dtPolyTypes.)
Gets the user defined area id.
Gets the polygon type. (See: #dtPolyTypes)
Defines the location of detail sub-mesh data within a dtMeshTile.
Flags representing the type of a navigation mesh polygon.

The Default Implementation
At construction: All area costs default to 1.0. All flags are included and none are excluded.
If a polygon has both an include and an exclude flag, it will be excluded.
The way filtering works, a navigation mesh polygon must have at least one flag set to ever be considered by a query. So a polygon with no flags will never be considered.
Setting the include flags to 0 will result in all polygons being excluded.
Custom Implementations
Implement a custom query filter by overriding the virtual PassFilter() and GetCost() functions. If this is done, both functions should be as fast as possible. Use cached local copies of data rather than accessing your own objects where possible.
Custom implementations do not need to adhere to the flags or cost logic used by the default implementation.
In order for A* searches to work properly, the cost should be proportional to the travel distance. Implementing a cost modifier less than 1.0 is likely to lead to problems during pathfinding.
@see NavMeshQuery
The hit parameter. (FLT_MAX if no wall hit.)
hitNormal The normal of the nearest wall hit. [(x, y, z)]
The index of the edge on the final polygon where the wall was hit.
Pointer to an array of reference ids of the visited polygons. [opt]
The cost of the path until hit.
Options for dtNavMeshQuery::raycast
The local path corridor corners for the agent. (Staight path.) [(x, y, z) * #ncorners]
The local path corridor corner flags. (See: #dtStraightPathFlags) [(flags) * #ncorners]
The reference id of the polygon being entered at the corner. [(polyRef) * #ncorners]
Vertex flags returned by dtNavMeshQuery::findStraightPath.
Options for dtNavMeshQuery::findStraightPath.

@par
All vertices are projected onto the xz-plane, so the y-values are ignored.

@par
All points are projected onto the xz-plane, so the y-values are ignored.
Called for each batch of unique polygons touched by the search area in dtNavMeshQuery::queryPolygons. This can be called multiple times for a single query.

member.name: T:NativeResourceCache
member.summary:
We only want 1 instance of a Resource class in C# and we want that to have 1 strong handle to native. So we need a WeakReference lookup everytime we get a Resource from native to match that class. This way GC can work for us and free anything we're no longer using anywhere, fantastic!
However sometimes GC is very good at it's job and will free Resources we don't keep a strong reference to in generation 0 or 1 immediately after usage. This can cause the resource to need to be loaded every frame. Or worse be finalized at unpredictable times.
So we keep a sliding memory cache of the Resources - realistically these only need to live for an extra frame. But it's probably nice to keep around for longer if they're going to be used on and off.

member.name: F:NativeResourceCache.WeakTable
member.summary: We still want a WeakReference cache because we might have a strong reference somewhere to a resource that has been expired from the cache. And we absolutely only want 1 instance of the resource.

member.name: M:NativeResourceCache.Tick
member.summary: Ticks the underlying MemoryCache to clear expired entries

member.name: M:NativeResourceCache.Clear
member.summary: Clear the cache when games are closed etc. ready for a

member.name: F:Steamworks.Dispatch.actionsToCall
member.summary: To be safe we don't call the continuation functions while iterating the Callback list. This is maybe overly safe because the only way this could be an issue is if the callback list is modified in the continuation which would only happen if starting or shutting down in the callback.

member.name: M:Steamworks.SteamFriends.OpenUserOverlay(Steamworks.SteamId,System.String)
member.summary: "steamid" - Opens the overlay web browser to the specified user or groups profile. "chat" - Opens a chat window to the specified user, or joins the group chat. "jointrade" - Opens a window to a Steam Trading session that was started with the ISteamEconomy/StartTrade Web API. "stats" - Opens the overlay web browser to the specified user's stats. "achievements" - Opens the overlay web browser to the specified user's achievements. "friendadd" - Opens the overlay in minimal mode prompting the user to add the target user as a friend. "friendremove" - Opens the overlay in minimal mode prompting the user to remove the target friend. "friendrequestaccept" - Opens the overlay in minimal mode prompting the user to accept an incoming friend invite. "friendrequestignore" - Opens the overlay in minimal mode prompting the user to ignore an incoming friend invite.

member.name: M:Steamworks.SteamFriends.OpenGameInviteOverlay(Steamworks.SteamId)
member.summary: Activates the Steam Overlay to open the invite dialog. Invitations sent from this dialog will be for the provided lobby.

member.summary: Requests the persona name and optionally the avatar of a specified user. NOTE: It's a lot slower to download avatars and churns the local cache, so if you don't need avatars, don't request them. returns true if we're fetching the data, false if we already have it

member.summary: Clientside, returns position of this 3D vector on local clients' screen in 2D coordinates based on the Camera
member.param: The vector to transform/project.
member.returns:
The position of this vector3 on the local clients' screen.
X and Y components are in range of 0 (left, top) to 1 (right, bottom).
The Z component stores whether this vector is behind the screen (<0) or in front of it (>0).

member.returns: Will return null if this vector is behind the screen, otherwise returns position of it on the local clients' screen.

member.summary: The camera's near clip plane distance. This is the closest distance this camera will be able to render. A good value for this is about 5. Below 5 and particularly below 1 you're going to start to see a lot of artifacts like z-fighting.

member.name: P:Sandbox.CameraComponent.ZFar
member.summary: The camera's far clip plane distance. This is the furthest distance this camera will be able to render. This value totally depends on the game you're making. Shorter the better, sensible ranges would be between about 1000 and 30000, but if you want it to be further out you can balance that out by making ZNear larger.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Component.IPressable
member.summary: A component that can be pressed. Like a button. This could be by a player USE'ing it, or by a player walking on it, or by an NPC. A call to Press should ALWAYS call release afterwards. Generally this is done by the player, where holding E presses the button, and releasing E stops pressing it. You need to handle edge cases where the player dies while holding etc.

member.name: T:Sandbox.CloneHelpers
member.summary: Provides helper methods for cloning objects and their members. We use a heuristic to determine if a type can be cloned by copy to speed up cloning. If we cannot copy something and we have to "clone" we do so by serializing to and deserializing from JSON. However, our goal is to copy as much as possible to avoid the serialization overhead.

This component is designed to be easy to use - since you only need to define the model. Although you can access the procedural (hidden) components, they aren't saved, so it's a waste of time.

member.name: M:Sandbox.NavMeshAgent.FindPhysicsGroundZ(Vector3)
member.summary:
We are tracing in the following interval (scale not accurate) x | | We start a certain distance above the agents capsules center | | | ------- | | | | x | -- Agent Capsule Center | | | ------- | | ~~~~~~~ -- Potential ground | | | x We trace down the same distance
In case of multiple hits we prefer the once closest to the agent's capsule center

member.name: M:Sandbox.NavMeshAgent.GetLookAhead(System.Single)

member.name: T:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion
member.summary: Adds an approximation of ambient occlusion using Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO). It darkens areas where ambient light is generally occluded from such as corners, crevices and surfaces that are close to each other.

member.name: F:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.SampleQuality.Low
member.summary: 9 samples

member.name: F:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.SampleQuality.Medium
member.summary: 16 samples

member.name: F:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.SampleQuality.High
member.summary: 25 samples

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.Intensity
member.summary: The intensity of the darkening effect. Has no impact on performance.

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.Radius
member.summary: Maximum distance of samples from pixel when determining its occlusion, in world units.

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.FalloffRange
member.summary: Gently reduce sample impact as it gets out of the effect's radius bounds

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.Quality
member.summary: Number of pixel samples taken to determine occlusion

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.DenoiseMode
member.summary: How we should denoise the effect

member.name: P:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.ThinCompensation
member.summary: Slightly reduce impact of samples further back to counter the bias from depth-based (incomplete) input scene geometry data

member.name: F:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.DenoiseModes.Spatial
member.summary: Applies spatial denoising to reduce noise by averaging pixel values within a local neighborhood. This method smooths out noise by considering the spatial relationship between pixels in a single frame.

member.name: F:Sandbox.AmbientOcclusion.DenoiseModes.Temporal
member.summary: Applies temporal denoising to reduce noise by averaging pixel values over multiple frames. This method leverages the temporal coherence of consecutive frames to achieve a noise-free result.

member.summary: The color map to use for the decal including transparency which masks the decal. This must be set for other textures to use the decal mask.

member.summary: The normal texture map to use for the decal.

member.summary: Attenuation angle controls how much the decal fades at an angle. At 0 it does not fade at all. Up to 1 it fades the most.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Decal.Size
member.summary: Sets the local size in units for the decal's projection. This is multiplied by the GameObject's world transform to get the final size.

member.summary: Determines the order the decal gets rendered in, the higher the layer the more priority it has. Decals on the same layer get automatically sorted by their GameObject ID.

summary.para: A that draws and handles input of a .

VR overlays draw over the top of the 3D scene, they will not be affected by lighting, post processing effects or anything else in the world.
This makes them ideal for HUDs or menus, or anything else that should be local to the HMD or tracked devices.
If you need something in the world, consider using WorldPanel and instead.

member.name: T:Sandbox.GameObjectSystem`1
member.summary: A syntax sugar wrapper around GameObjectSystem, which allows you to access your system using SystemName.Current instead of Scene.GetSystem.

member.name: T:Sandbox.TimedCallbackList
member.summary: Keeps a list of callbacks The intention of this is that in the future we'll have a nice window that will show the relative performance of each callback, and allow you to disable them to debug.

member.name: T:Sandbox.CallbackBatch
member.summary: We want to execute callbacks in a predictable order. This happens naturally when spawning one GameObject, but when spawning a scene, or a prefab, we want to hold the calls to things like OnEnable and call them all after OnStart or whatever has been called on all the objects in the batch.

member.name: M:Sandbox.CallbackBatch.Batch(System.String)
member.summary: Add callbacks to the previous batch (or create one). This allows for one single batch, the most outer one, and won't create a new batch for inner ones. This is used when doing things like deserializing a map, so all the OnEnable etc are executed at the same time, and in the right order.

member.name: M:Sandbox.CallbackBatch.Isolated(System.String)
member.summary: Collect callbacks in this scope and execute them immediately at the end of this batch. This is used for things like gameobject Clones, where we're going to want access to the object straight after creating it.. and if we're inside a Batch then OnEnable etc won't have been called, so it will be confusing to everyone.

member.name: T:Sandbox.CommonCallback
member.summary: A list of component methods that are deferred and batched into groups, and exected in group order. This is used to ensure that components are initialized in a predictable order. The order of this enum is critical.

member.summary: An opportunity for the component to load any data they need to load

member.summary: Component has been enabled

member.name: T:Sandbox.GameObject
member.summary: An object in the scene. Functionality is added using Components. A GameObject has a transform, which explains its position, rotation and scale, relative to its parent. It also has a name, and can be enabled or disabled. When disabled, the GameObject is still in the scene, but the components don't tick and are all disabled.

member.name: M:Sandbox.GameTransform.SetLocalTransformFast(Transform@)
member.summary: Sets the local transform without firing a bunch of "transform changed" callbacks. The assumption is that you're changing a bunch of child transforms, and will then call transform changed on the root, which will then invoke all the callbacks just once. This is what the animation system does!

member.name: T:Sandbox.BroadcastAttribute
member.summary: Marks a method as being an RPC that when invoked will be called for all connected clients including the host. The state of the object the RPC is called on will be up-to-date including its and any properties with the or attributes by the time the method is called on remote clients. The only except is any synchronized properties marked with which will generally only be received every network tick.

member.name: T:Sandbox.AuthorityAttribute
member.summary:
Marks a method as being an RPC specifically targeted to the owner of the , or the host if the doesn't have an owner.
The state of the object the RPC is called on will be up-to-date including its and any properties with the or attributes by the time the method is called on remote clients. The only except is any synchronized properties marked with which will generally only be received every network tick.

member.summary: Anyone can invoke this.

member.summary: Only the host can invoke this.

member.name: F:Sandbox.NetPermission.OwnerOnly
member.summary: Only the owner can invoke this. If the action is static, this works the same way as .

member.summary: The panel on which the event is being called. For example, if you have a button with a label.. when the button gets clicked the actual click event might come from the label. This is mainly of use with Razor callbacks, where you want to get the actual panel that created the event.

If you set this to InputMode.Game, this panel will redirect its inputs to the game, which means for example that if you're focused on this panel and press space, it'll send the jump button to the game.

This is particularly useful if you want to delete a GameObject but want to wait for sounds or particles to conclude.

This will add to be watched (if not null), and remove from being watched (if not null). If both assemblies aren't null, they will be added to be swapped when is next called, and true is returned.

member.summary: Returns the queue of assemblies that will be swapped when is called. These are added using the method.
member.returns: The mapping of assembly replacements.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Hotload.IInstanceUpgrader
member.summary:
Interface to implement a custom object instance upgrade process for types that match a condition. Instances of any derived types will be created and added to a instance that uses on the declaring assembly of the derived type, unless a has been specified.
You can configure which order s are queried by using , and / or .

member.name: P:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.Swaps
member.summary: A mapping of assembles to swap with new versions.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.GetNewType(System.Type)
member.summary: When hotswapping this will switch types from the old assembly into the type from the new assembly.
member.param: The old type.
member.returns: The new type, or null if no substitution exists. The old type will be returned if it's still valid (not from a swapped assembly).

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.GetNewInstance(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns an upgraded version of the given object, replacing any types from a swapped-out assembly with their new up-to-date types. The result is cached, so if you pass the same object to this method multiple times it will always return the same instance. Fields inside the new instance may not be initialized until later in the hotload.
member.param: Object to upgrade.
member.returns: An upgraded version of the given object.

member.summary: Logs a message in the current hotload.

member.summary: Logs an exception in the current hotload.

member.summary: Called when this upgrader has been added to a instance.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.OnClearCache
member.summary: Called between hotloads, should clear up any cached resources that won't be needed in future hotloads.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.ShouldProcessType(System.Type)
member.summary: Check to see if this upgrader can possibly handle the given type.
member.param: Type to upgrade an instance of.
member.returns: True if this upgrader should attempt to upgrade an instance of the given type.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.OnTryCreateNewInstance(System.Object,System.Object@)
member.summary: If this upgrader supports upgrading the given , returns true and assigns to be the value that should replace . This method doesn't need to copy the inner state of the instance across, but just creates an empty instance to be populated later.

remarks.para: It's safe to just directly assign to if the type isn't declared in a replaced assembly.
Returning true will cause to be called immediately after this method, which schedules copying the state of the old instance to the new one.

member.param: Instance that should be replaced / upgraded.
If this method returns true, this should contain the instance that replaces , or itself if no replacement is necessary.
member.returns: True if this upgrader handles the replacement of the given .

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.OnTryUpgradeInstance(System.Object,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called immediately after if it returned true, or on instances from fields that can't be re-assigned (see ). This method determines what kind of extra processing is required for the given replacement.

remarks.para: In this method we can call things like , or to handle copying values from the old instance to the new one.
If should be cached as the canonical replacement for , call here.
If finalization should be suppressed, call .

member.param: Original instance that is being replaced / upgraded from.
New instance that replaces , or itself if no replacement is necessary.
True if was created outside of the hotloading system, for example when the containing field has set to true. Otherwise, when false, will have been called just before this method.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.InstanceUpgrader.OnProcessInstance(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Perform extra field processing on a new instance that has previously been created by this upgrader in . This is a good place to discover any other instances that should be upgraded that are stored in , which can be upgraded by calling .
member.param: The original instance that was upgraded.
Upgraded version of , or even the same object if no upgrade was required.
member.returns: Roughly how many instances were processed by this method. Only used for performance stats.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Hotload.SimplifySwaps

member.name: T:Sandbox.Upgraders.AutoSkipUpgrader
member.summary: Instance upgrader that will try to automatically find types are definitely skippable. This upgrader isn't added automatically, you can enable it by calling .

remarks.para: We attempt this almost last (just before ) so that any upgraders that handle specific types will be chosen first, and therefore stop those types from being skipped. Adds any skippable types it finds to a cache, and forces to process them.
This performs an under-approximation, but you can use to mark any types it misses that you know are safe to skip.

summary.para: If set on a type, it (and its descendants) can be created and manipulated via the TypeLibrary system, and therefore also in action graphs.
Note that this is only useful for our internal libraries because everything in compiled (addons) assemblies is accessible anyway.

member.summary: This is a hash of loaded assembly names. We can use it to make sure we're using the same code as the server. This is important when it comes to things like decoding network messages and datatables - because if the code is different we're going to get errors, because it could expect different data.

member.name: T:Sandbox.ChangeAttribute
member.summary:
This will invoke a method when the property changes. It can be used with any property but is especially useful when combined with [Sync] or [ConVar].
If no name is provided, we will try to call On[PropertyName]Changed. The callback should have 2 arguments - oldValue and newValue, both of the same type as the property itself.

member.name: P:Sandbox.ChangeAttribute.Name
member.summary: Name of the method to call on change. If no name is provided, we will try to call On[PropertyName]Changed.

member.name: P:Sandbox.EventAttribute.Priority
member.summary: Events with lower numbers are run first. This defaults to 0, so setting it to -1 will mean your event will run before all other events that don't define it. Setting it to 1 would mean it'll run after all events that don't.

member.name: T:Sandbox.SkipHotloadAttribute
member.summary: Skip processing a specific field, or any fields in a type marked by this attribute. Field processing will still occur if a type marked by this attribute was defined in a swapped assembly.
member.remarks: This is nice for speeding up hotloading, particularly when used on types with lots of fields, or on fields that are the only path to large networks of objects that all don't need replacing during the hotload.

member.name: T:Sandbox.SuppressNullKeyWarningAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a member with or type, don't warn if the key of an item becomes null during a hotload because a type is removed. You should only use this attribute if you're sure that it's safe to quietly remove entries.

member.name: T:Sandbox.IHotloadManaged
member.summary: During hotloads, instances of types implementing this interface will be notified when they get replaced.

member.name: M:Sandbox.IHotloadManaged.Destroyed(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object})
member.summary: Called when this instance is about to be replaced during a hotload. The implementor may optionally write to the dictionary, which gets passed to the new replacing instance when is called on it.
member.param: Dictionary to store values to pass to the new instance.

member.name: M:Sandbox.IHotloadManaged.Created(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyDictionary{System.String,System.Object})
member.summary: Called when this instance has been created during a hotload, replacing an instance from an older version of the containing assembly. The parameter will contain any values populated when was called on the old instance that was replaced.
member.param: Dictionary containing values written by the old instance.

member.name: M:Sandbox.IHotloadManaged.Persisted
member.summary: Called when this instance is about to be processed, but not replaced.

member.name: M:Sandbox.IHotloadManaged.Failed
member.summary: Called when this instance could not be upgraded during a hotload, and any references to it have been replaced with null. This is a good time to clean up any unmanaged resources related to this instance.

member.name: T:Sandbox.MethodArgumentsAttribute
member.summary: Specify the types of arguments a method should have. Typically used with event attributes to throw an exception if an event attribute is added to a method with incorrect arguments.

member.name: P:Sandbox.PropertyAttribute.Name
member.summary: The internal name of this property. This should be lowercase with no spaces. If unset the lowercased C# variable name is used.

member.name: P:Sandbox.PropertyAttribute.Title
member.summary: The user friendly name of this property. If unset, it will be auto generated from C# variable name.

member.name: M:Sandbox.PropertyAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: The internal name of this property. This should be lowercase with no spaces.

member.name: T:Sandbox.KeyPropertyAttribute
member.summary: Mark this property as the key property - which means that it can represent the whole object in a single line, while usually offering an advanced mode to view the entire object.

member.name: T:Sandbox.InlineEditorAttribute
member.summary: Tell the editor to try to display inline editing for this property, rather than hiding it behind a popup etc.

member.name: T:Sandbox.RangeAttribute
member.summary: Mark this property as a ranged float/int. In inspector we'll be able to create a slider instead of a text entry. TODO: Replace this with the System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.Range one - move step and clamped to their own attributes

member.name: T:Sandbox.StringLiteralOnlyAttribute
member.summary: Ask codegen to shit itself if the parameter isn't passed in as a string literal

member.name: T:Sandbox.HideAttribute
member.summary: Hide this in tools/editors.

member.name: T:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorAttribute
member.summary: An attribute that can be added to a custom class for special code generation behavior. They'll then be applied to methods and properties when they are decorated with that attribute.

member.name: P:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorAttribute.Priority
member.summary: Attributes with a higher priority will wrap the target first. The default priority is 0.

member.name: P:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorAttribute.CallbackName
member.summary: The name of the callback method. This can be a fully qualified static method callback or a simple callback to invoke on the target object if the method or property target is not static.

member.name: P:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorAttribute.Type
member.summary: The type of code generation you want to do. You will need to specify whether it should apply to instance or static methods and properties using the and flags.

member.name: M:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorAttribute.#ctor(Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Perform code generation for a method or property.
member.param: The type of code generation you want to do. You will need to specify whether it should apply to instance or static methods and properties using the and flags.
The name of the callback method. This can be a fully qualified static method callback or a simple callback to invoke on the target object if the method or property target is not static.
Attributes with a higher priority will wrap the target first. The default priority is 0.

member.name: T:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags
member.summary: Used to specify what type of code generation to perform.

member.name: F:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags.WrapPropertyGet
member.summary: Wrap the get accessor of a property.

member.name: F:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags.WrapPropertySet
member.summary: Wrap the set accessor of a property.

member.name: F:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags.WrapMethod
member.summary: Wrap a method call.

member.name: F:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags.Static
member.summary: Apply this to a static property or method.

member.name: F:Sandbox.CodeGeneratorFlags.Instance
member.summary: Apply this to an instance property or method.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1
member.summary: Circular buffer, push pop and index access is always O(1).

member.name: F:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1._start
member.summary: The _start. Index of the first element in buffer.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1._end
member.summary: The _end. Index after the last element in the buffer.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1._size
member.summary: The _size. Buffer size.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Buffer capacity. Must be positive.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.#ctor(System.Int32,`0[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Buffer capacity. Must be positive.
Items to fill buffer with. Items length must be less than capacity. Suggestion: use Skip(x).Take(y).ToArray() to build this argument from any enumerable.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Capacity
member.summary: Maximum capacity of the buffer. Elements pushed into the buffer after maximum capacity is reached (IsFull = true), will remove an element.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.IsFull
member.summary: Boolean indicating if Circular is at full capacity. Adding more elements when the buffer is full will cause elements to be removed from the other end of the buffer.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.IsEmpty
member.summary: True if has no elements.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Size
member.summary: Current buffer size (the number of elements that the buffer has).

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Front
member.summary: Element at the front of the buffer - this[0].
member.returns: The value of the element of type T at the front of the buffer.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Back
member.summary: Element at the back of the buffer - this[Size - 1].
member.returns: The value of the element of type T at the back of the buffer.

member.name: P:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Index access to elements in buffer. Index does not loop around like when adding elements, valid interval is [0;Size[
member.param: Index of element to access.
member.exception: Thrown when index is outside of [; Size[ interval.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.PushBack(`0)
member.summary:
Pushes a new element to the back of the buffer. Back()/this[Size-1] will now return this element.
When the buffer is full, the element at Front()/this[0] will be popped to allow for this new element to fit.
member.param: Item to push to the back of the buffer

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.PushFront(`0)
member.summary:
Pushes a new element to the front of the buffer. Front()/this[0] will now return this element.
When the buffer is full, the element at Back()/this[Size-1] will be popped to allow for this new element to fit.
member.param: Item to push to the front of the buffer

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.PopBack
member.summary: Removes the element at the back of the buffer. Decreasing the Buffer size by 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.PopFront
member.summary: Removes the element at the front of the buffer. Decreasing the Buffer size by 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Clear
member.summary: Clears the contents of the array. Size = 0, Capacity is unchanged.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.ToArray
member.summary: Copies the buffer contents to an array, according to the logical contents of the buffer (i.e. independent of the internal order/contents)
member.returns: A new array with a copy of the buffer contents.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.ToArraySegments
member.summary:
Get the contents of the buffer as 2 ArraySegments. Respects the logical contents of the buffer, where each segment and items in each segment are ordered according to insertion.
Fast: does not copy the array elements. Useful for methods like Send(IList<ArraySegment<Byte>>).
Segments may be empty.
member.returns: An IList with 2 segments corresponding to the buffer content.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator that iterates through this buffer.
member.returns: An enumerator that can be used to iterate this collection.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Increment(System.Int32@)
member.summary: Increments the provided index variable by one, wrapping around if necessary.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.Decrement(System.Int32@)
member.summary: Decrements the provided index variable by one, wrapping around if necessary.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.CircularBuffer`1.InternalIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts the index in the argument to an index in _buffer
member.returns: The transformed index.
member.param: External index.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.HashSetEx`1.EnumerateLocked(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates the list, increments iterating before and after. When we finished iterating, and nothing else is iterating, runs deferred actions. IMPORTANT: Don't expose this IEnumerable to users directly - because they might purposefully not dispose it?

member.name: T:Sandbox.Utility.Noise
member.summary:
Provides access to coherent noise utilities.
All of these functions should return between 0 and 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.Perlin(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: 2D Perlin noise function. For a thread-safe alternative with more options, use .
member.param: Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.
member.returns: Resulting noise at given coordinates, in range of 0 to 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.Perlin(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: 3D Perlin noise function. For a thread-safe alternative with more options, use .
member.param: Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.
Input on the Z axis.
member.returns: Resulting noise at given coordinates, in range of 0 to 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.Simplex(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: 2D Simplex noise function. For a thread-safe alternative with more options, use .
member.param: Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.
member.returns: Resulting noise at given coordinates, in range of 0 to 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.Simplex(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: 3D Simplex noise function. For a thread-safe alternative with more options, use .
member.param: Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.
Input on the Z axis.
member.returns: Resulting noise at given coordinates, in range of 0 to 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.Fbm(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Fractional Brownian Motion noise, a.k.a. Fractal Perlin noise. For a thread-safe alternative with more options, use with .
member.param: Number of octaves for the noise. Higher values are slower but produce more detailed results. 3 is a good starting point.
Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.
Input on the Z axis.
member.returns: Resulting noise at given coordinates, in range of 0 to 1.

member.name: M:Sandbox.Utility.Noise.FbmVector(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Fractional Brownian Motion noise, a.k.a. Fractal Perlin noise.

Input on the X axis.
Input on the Y axis.

member.name: M:Sandbox.SandboxSystemExtensions.CollapseWhiteSpaceRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern:
\\s+
Explanation:
Match a whitespace character atomically at least once.

member.name: M:Sandbox.SandboxSystemExtensions.CollapseWhiteSpace(System.String)
member.summary: Collapse sequences of whitespace into a single whitespace

member.name: M:Sandbox.SandboxSystemExtensions.CollapseSpacesAndTabsRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern:
[ \t]+
Explanation:
Match a character in the set [\t ] atomically at least once.

member.name: M:Sandbox.SandboxSystemExtensions.RemoveSpacesAroundLineBreaksRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern:
(?<=\\n|\\u2029)[ \\t]+|[ \\t]+(?=\\n|\\u2029)
Explanation:
Match with 2 alternative expressions, atomically.
Match a sequence of expressions.
Zero-width positive lookbehind.
Match a character in the set [\n\u2029] right-to-left.
Match a character in the set [\t ] atomically at least once.
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [\t ] atomically at least once.
Zero-width positive lookahead.
Match a character in the set [\n\u2029].

member.name: T:Sandbox.Spline
member.summary:
Collection of curves in 3D space. Shape and behavior of the curves are controled through points , each with customizable handles, roll, scale, and up vectors. Two consecutive points define a segment/curve of the spline.
By adjusting the handles both smooth and sharp corners can be created. The spline can also be turned into a loop, combined with linear tangents this can be used to create polygons. Splines can also be used used for animations, camera movements, marking areas, or procedural geometry generation.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Spline.Point
member.summary:
Point that defines part of the spline. Two consecutive points define a segment of the spline. The , / Handles and / properties are used to define the shape of the spline.
P1 (Position) P1 (In) P1 (Out) oXo / \ / \ -/ \- / \ | | P0 X X P2

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Position
member.summary: The position of the spline point.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.In
member.summary: Position of the In handle relative to the point position.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Out
member.summary: Position of the Out handle relative to the point position.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Mode
member.summary: Describes how the spline should behave when entering/leaving a point. The mmode and the handles In and Out position will determine the transition between segments.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Roll
member.summary: Roll/Twist around the tangent axis.

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Scale
member.summary: X = Scale Length, Y = Scale Width, Z = Scale Height

member.name: F:Sandbox.Spline.Point.Up
member.summary: Custom up vector at a spline point, can be used to calculate tangent frames (transforms) along the spline. This allows fine grained control over the orientation of objects following the spline.

member.name: T:Sandbox.Spline.HandleMode
member.summary: Describes how the spline should behave when entering/leaving a point.
